DataElement.preferredName: Disease Progression Or Disease Transformation Difference Myeloproliferative Neoplasm Or Acute Myeloid Leukemia Subtype Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The indicator that describes whether or not if there was a disease progression or transformation to a different myeloproliferative neoplasm or acute myeloid leukemia subtype.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Disease Progression Or Disease Transformation Difference Myeloproliferative Neoplasm Or Acute Myeloid Leukemia Subtype
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The worsening of a disease over time._An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise._A conversion from one disease diagnosis to another, which may be considered a progression to a worsening state._The quality of being unlike or dissimilar._A clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder, characterized by proliferation in the bone marrow of one or more of the myeloid (i.e., granulocytic, erythroid, megakaryocytic, and mast cell) lineages. It is primarily a neoplasm of adults. (WHO 2008)_An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise._A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues. The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia; 3) Therapy-related AML; 4) AML not otherwise specified. The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML is 20% (WHO classification)._A group forming a type within a larger type.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Disease Progression Or Disease Transformation Difference
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The worsening of a disease over time.:An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.:A conversion from one disease diagnosis to another, which may be considered a progression to a worsening state.:The quality of being unlike or dissimilar.

Concepts.definition: A process that manifests as the worsening of a disease over time.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
A conversion from one disease diagnosis to another, which may be considered a progression to a worsening state.
The quality of being unlike or dissimilar.

Property.preferredName: Myeloproliferative Neoplasm Or Acute Myeloid Leukemia Subtype
Property.preferredDefinition: A clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder, characterized by proliferation in the bone marrow of one or more of the myeloid (i.e., granulocytic, erythroid, megakaryocytic, and mast cell) lineages. It is primarily a neoplasm of adults. (WHO 2008):An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.:A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues. The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia; 3) Therapy-related AML; 4) AML not otherwise specified. The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML is 20% (WHO classification).:A group forming a type within a larger type.

Concepts.definition: A group of myeloid neoplasms that includes the following: chronic myeloid leukemia, BCR-ABL1 positive; polycythemia vera; essential thrombocythemia;  primary myelofibrosis; chronic neutrophilic leukemia; chronic eosinophilic leukemia, not otherwise specified; and myeloproliferative neoplasm, unclassifiable.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.

A clonal expansion of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, blood or other tissues. The classification of acute myeloid leukemias (AMLs) encompasses four major categories: 1) AML with recurrent genetic abnormalities; 2) AML with multilineage dysplasia; 3) Therapy-related AML; 4) AML not otherwise specified. The required bone marrow or peripheral blood blast percentage for the diagnosis of AML is 20% (WHO classification).
A group forming a type within a larger type.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).
